abstract.p: Dr Paul R Epstein letter comments on July 9 article on power blackout in New York City during recent heat wave (S)

block.p: Two July 9 front-page articles on recent power failures highlight the need for stand-alone energy sources. As demands of an affluent, wired society outstrip capacity, ''off-grid'' energy sources become essential, just as they are for poor countries with inadequate systems and supplies.

Two July 9 front-page articles on recent power failures highlight the need for stand-alone energy sources. As demands of an affluent, wired society outstrip capacity, ''off-grid'' energy sources become essential, just as they are for poor countries with inadequate systems and supplies.

As energy demands grow and oil prices rise, surely it is time for a national debate on energy policies. Several principles may help: Low energy architecture and co-generation can dramatically improve energy efficiency. Manufacturing stand-alone renewable energy sources, like fuel cells, solar and wind-driven units, can provide security for medical laboratories, pump and purify water in developing countries and catalyze economic growth while helping to stabilize the climate. PAUL R. EPSTEIN, M.D. Boston, July 9, 1999
The writer is associate director, the Center for Health and the Global Environment, Harvard Medical School.
